prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Arena Stage Historical Documents, 1950-1998, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Arena Stage was launched in 1950 by its co-founders Zelda Fichandler, Thomas C. Fichandler, and the late Edward Mangum in an abandoned movie house, the Hippodrome, which was converted into an arena, seating 247 people. Mangum, a teacher from George Washington University, and Zelda Fichandler, one of his students, were the vibrant and successful play makers who filled the vacuum left by closing of the National Theater in 1948. Arena Stage became one of the first resident theaters in the United States.

She Stoops to Conquer was the first of 55 productions in the first Arena playhouse, put on between August 1950 and July 1955. Through these first five years it learned much about the "rediscovered" arena format, which proved economically and artistically well-suited to the twentieth-century American theater. Although the Hippodrome played to full houses much of the time, the capacity was to small to support the costs of production. At the end of a successful American premiere run Agatha Christie's The Mousetrap,the theater was closed for a year to allow time to search for a new home.

In November 1956, Arena Stage reopened with Arthur Miller's View from the Bridge in the converted Hospitality Hall of the Old Heurich Brewery, referred to as "The Old Vat." Outstanding among the 40 plays presented at the "The Old Vat" were Summer of the 17th Doll, The Lady's Not for Burning, The Caine Mutiny Court Martial, and the American premiere of The Egg.

In October 1961, the Arena Stage Company broke ground at its current Southwest Washington, D.C. location with a dazzling inaugural production of Brecht's The Caucasian Chalk Circle. Some of the many memorable productions in the present Arena include the world premiere production of The Great White Hope and the American premiere of Indians, both of which went to Broadway.

Having just celebrated its Fiftieth Anniversary, the theater performs for more than 250,000 patrons during its September to June season. With an operating budget of $11 million, the Arena Stage boasts three performing spaces: the 816-seat Fichandler Stage, the 514-seat Kreeger Theater, and the 180-seat Old Vat Room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The Arena Stage Historical Documents Collections contains materials from the early part of Arena Stage's history including photographs, slides, reports, papers, newspaper articles and reviews.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged alphabetically by subject/topic.
